result.execSummary:
The defendant was charged with both OWI (4th) and Operating w/ PAC (4th). The defendant was found guilty of OWI (4th) and the other charge, Operating w/ PAC (4th) was dismissed by the court.

  • Matthew David Mclaughlin was found guilty of OWI (4th), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(1)(a).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: Cash bond in cases 22CM46, 22CM49, 22CF262 shall be applied to fines/costs in those cases w/balance being applied to fines/costs in 22CF263 - any remaining amount due in 22CF263 to be paid as a condition of extended supervision.

Defendant shall not consume alcohol.

Defendant shall not possess/consume any controlled substance without a valid prescription.

Defendant shall not enter establishments whose primary purpose is the sale/serving of alcohol.

Defendant shall not operate any motor vehicle unless he has a valid driver's license.

Defendant shall participate in all counseling, assessments, and/or treatment programs directed by the probation agent, and shall complete any recommended treatment.

Defendant shall, within three (3) days, contact the Washington County Jail for purposes of supplying a biological specimen for DNA analysis.  Defendant has the right to request expungement of DNA analysis in writing through the Department of Justice. 

Defendant shall maintain absolute sobriety.

Defendant shall obtain/maintain full-time employment, schooling or combination of both.
